FacilityName: Kraft Heinz Foods Company, Fort Myers

_prev_prog_3.Description:
As a vital element of the facility's prevention program, Kraft Heinz North America inaugurated a Process Safety Management Program as mandated by OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  Kraft Heinz North America has implemented strict preventive maintenance and operating procedures in compliance with the Process Safety Management program. Additionally, the facility has developed an Emergency Action Plan where the release of ammonia is specially covered in the plan and contains all required actions in the event of a release of ammonia.

As part of the facility's prevention programs, emergency evacuation and operational training is conducted for employees and new hires.  Accidental release prevention, training and awareness are reinforced annually, and as operations at the facility dictates.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
KRAFT HEINZ NORTH AMERICA - Executive Summary





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Kraft Heinz North America operates the commercial Bagel Bites production facility in Fort Myers, Florida. It is the policy of Heinz to comply with all applicable federal, state and local environmental and safety laws and regulations, and to conduct its business in an environmentally sound manner that avoids any unreasonable adverse impact on the environment or its neighboring community.



In keeping with this policy, Kraft Heinz North America has developed and implemented OSHA's Process Safety Management and EPA's Risk Management Programs to ensure the safety of our employees and the surrounding community. The Risk Management Programs includes: (1) to identify potentially hazardous chemicals at the facility, (2) for maintaining a safe working environment and, thereby, help prevent the release of hazardous chemicals and (3) for minimizing the consequences of a release should one occur.





Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Kraft Heinz North America, Fort Myers facility, makes Bagel Bite food products. The major processes at the Fort Myers facility include flour handling and storage, ingredient mixing, sauce making, dough proofing, bagel baking, and product packaging and distribution. Raw materials are delivered to this facility by trucks.



The only RMP regulated chemical handled by Kraft Heinz North America at the Fort Myers facility is anhydrous ammonia. Anhydrous ammonia is used at the facility in the refrigeration system for cooling the building, cooling and freezing products. The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop system. Anhydrous ammonia is delivered to the facility by supplier tank trucks to initially charge the system and occasionally thereafter to top-off the system if needed, to replenish from periodic maintenance.



Kraft Heinz North America has in place policies that limit the amount of ammonia a

t the facility. In addition, this facility complies with the IIAR and ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 15 for ammonia refrigeration.



Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios



As stipulated in EPA guidelines, 40 CFR Part 68.25, the worst-case and alternate-case release scenarios were calculated for the covered process at the facility and the results are shown in Section 2 and 3 of the RMP Submit and also held on file at the Heinz facility.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps



The Kraft Heinz North America, Fort Myers facility is subject to both EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Program and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Program. Under both of these programs, the facility has outlined specific procedures that it follows to prevent or minimize the release of analysis (PHA) of the ammonia system and will repeat this process at least every 5 years. The purpose of the PHA is to provide a systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards associated with the ammonia system. In addition, the facility performs regular training of its employees to ensure that the procedures developed for the safe use and handling of ammonia is adhered to all the time. Finally, the facility has a regular inspection and maintenance program to ensure that the ammonia system is operated and maintained according to specific ammonia industry safety standards. 



It is Kraft Heinz North America policy and belief that safe operating and maintenance practices and accident prevention programs are the key to obtaining safe operation and achieving accident prevention. 



Five Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases involving the ammonia system in the last five years that resulted in on-site or off-site consequences, injuries or required incident investigation.



Emergency Program 



Kraft Heinz North America has devised a comprehensive emergency program, designed to protect both employees an

d the community in the event of a release. The Heinz Fort Myers facility Emergency Action Plan focuses on evacuation of the facility in the event of an ammonia emergency, with the assistance of local emergency response agencies performing rescue, firefighting, first-aid, medical treatment, and other response functions. The facility maintains a written Emergency Action Plan which documents specific procedures to be implemented in the event of various emergencies, including ammonia releases. The Emergency Action Plan includes procedures for facility evacuation, as well as notification of the local emergency response agencies which are responsible for notifying the public. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the facility that would require modified procedures.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



No changes to the ammonia refrigeration processes are planned at this time. However, the process will be subjected to regular process hazard analyses reviews for the purpose of identifying and implementing potential improvements. Facility personnel will also periodically review all potential opportunities to improve the safety of our personnel, the surrounding community, and the ammonia refrigeration process.
